moves.1. Nf3: This was a Gameknot game I played.
moves.1... d5 2. g3 c5 3. Bg2 Nc6 4. d4:
She turns it into a reversed Grünfeld Defence
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnfeld_Defence
I would have preferred a reversed King's Indian Defence 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King%27s_Indian_Defence
moves.4... Nf6 5. O-O e6: I am playing one of the quieter ways of handling it.
moves.6. c4: I suspect we are both using opening databases.
moves.6... dxc4 7. dxc5 Qa5: I thought I may give her more problems with the queens on.
moves.8. Qc2 Bxc5 9. Qxc4: so we both have recaptured the pawns.
moves.9... O-O: We are coming to the end of the opening databases, and Gameknot post-match computer seems to think we both start making mistakes...
moves.10. e4: This seems a reasonable move, seizing territory, but Gameknot computer  prefers 10. Bd2
moves.10... e5: and this seems reasonable, stopping the pawn from advancing again, but Gameknot computer prefers … b6
moves.11. Nc3: And here the Gameknot computer likes 11. Bd2
moves.11... Be6: I didn't think I had any advantage here, and the Gameknot computer agrees.
moves.12. Qe2 Rfd8 13. Bg5 Bg4 14. Bxf6: I wasn't too afraid of my pawns being doubled - I felt on an open board like this, the bishops are better than knights and the doubled pawns give an element of central control. In particular e5 is protected by a pawn now.
moves.14... gxf6 15. Nd5: This is a good move, forcing me to defend.
moves.15... Kg7: Like so. I now have a threat of Nd4.
moves.16... Qxe1: So I take the queens off.
moves.17... Rac8: I centralise the other rook, wondering how on earth I'm going to win this....
moves.20. Nc3:
And this retreat is the start of her problems, after the exchange she is left with weak isolated pawns on the queen-side and my rook can penetrate to the second rank. Clear advantage to black now.
I would guess she was afraid that 20. Rab1 would lose a pawn, as I could exchange rooks and take on b2, but then her rook goes to the 7th rank and is very active - she would have had enough compensation for the pawn.
moves.22... b6: So I deal with that threat.
moves.23. a4: Presumably trying to exchange off weak queen-side pawns.
moves.25... Rxa5: I take. I am a clear pawn up, but not only that my pieces are in dominating positions.
moves.26. f4: Trying to exchange pawns, or close down the king side - restrict my bishop in some way.
moves.26... Kf8: I decide to centralise my king.
moves.27... Ke7: Gameknot computer doesn't like move and prefers Bg4 attacking his rook. Fritz likes Bg4 or Rc7.
moves.28. Rbc1: And it doesn't like this move either. The reason was white could now do some exchanging - rook takes bishop, king takes back, then bishop check on h3 and white wins the exchange back. Normally when material down, a side wants to exchange pawns but not pieces, but this position is an exception. White's bishop is a bad bishop, blocked in by the pawn on e4. We will see later exactly how bad it becomes..
moves.31. Ra1 Rc8c7 32. h3 Bc8 33. Ra3 a6: White is still in the game. the Bc8 has limited scope.
moves.34... Rd7 35. Re3 Rd1+ 36. Bf1 Bb7 37. K: This is a dreadful move, allowing black to obtain an overwhelming position.
moves.39... Rd8d2: No neither white king nor white bishop can move.
moves.40. g4: This is a slight error. better c4 immediately.
moves.40... h6: To stop any more advances of the king side pawns.
moves.41. Rb3: Again, c4 immediately was called for.
moves.41... Kd6: This is a mistake. Better was Rc1 or Rc2 to prevent c4.
moves.42... Bc6: I break the pin on the b file.
moves.43. Rba3 Kc5 44. Rxa6 bxc4 45. Ra7: This is another mistake. White hasn't got the time to be chasing after the king side pawns. Best was Rc3.
moves.47. Rc7: Computer thinks Rxc3 is better, but it is academic, this position is lost. I am not sure there is any need to comment on the rest.
and white, about to lose the last pawn throws in the sponge.
